['"An empty stomach is a grumpy heart." - This maxim suggests that when one is hungry, they are also unhappy or irritable.', '"A hungry man is an angry man." - Similar to the previous maxim, this adage implies that hunger can lead to negative emotions like anger.', '"There\'s no use crying over spilt milk." - This common saying may not seem directly related to hunger, but it can be applied to situations where one feels they have missed an opportunity (e.g., food) and must now cope with the consequences.', '"Bite off more than you can chew." - This idiom warns against taking on too much at once, as it can lead to feeling overwhelmed or unsatisfied.', '"Don\'t count your chickens before they hatch." - Similar to the previous idiom, this saying advises caution when making plans that rely on uncertain outcomes (e.g., food).', '"A little hunger never hurt anyone." - While not necessarily negative, this maxim acknowledges that hunger can be a natural and manageable experience without resorting to unhealthy or extreme measures to address it.', '"Food for thought." - This phrase, while not directly related to hunger, acknowledges the connection between mental and physical nourishment (e.g., thinking about food can provide sustenance for the mind).', '"Eat your heart out." - While this idiom may seem negative, it can also be interpreted as encouraging someone to enjoy their food and not worry about others\' opinions (e.g., "eating your heart out" over a delicious meal).', '"Breadwinner." - This term acknowledges the importance of food in providing for one\'s basic needs and supporting oneself or one\'s family.', '"Food is love." - This phrase, while subjective, highlights the emotional connection many people feel towards food and the nourishment it provides beyond just sustenance (e.g., comfort, nostalgia).']
